reasoning: The critique targets a genuinely important part of the essay’s case against WAM-convergence (the move from moral realism to ‘alien’ morality and hence low motivation), but it is not the sole support for the essay’s overall outlook (which also leans on antirealism-divergence arguments and on trade/threats/blockers), so centrality is moderate. As a countermodel, it does undermine any claim of necessity from realism→alienation, but the essay only claims this is ‘likely’ and also discusses externalism/internalism and motivational failure even given true beliefs; the critique doesn’t engage those, so it only partially weakens the attacked step. The main idea (response-dependent/constructivist realisms can make moral truths closer to human psychology) is broadly correct, but it somewhat mislabels Cornell realism/Boyd as response-dependent and overstates how much the essay’s ‘central pessimistic argument’ would collapse. It is focused, clear, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Response-dependent realism could anchor moral facts close to human intuitions
